title: Cryogenic Electron Diffraction Study of Abundant Charge Density Waves in Kagome Metal ScV6Sn6
content: Crystals featuring Kagome lattice structures have attracted significant interest and have been studied as a novel platform to manipulate quantum materials since they hold unique electron band properties, including flat bands, van Hove singularities and Dirac points that appear due to its distinctive lattice configuration. Unusual charge density waves (CDW) and superconductivities, attributed to strong electron correlations, have been reported in the Kagome family AV3Sb5 (A = K, Rb, Cs) [1]. Although various experimental techniques have been employed to study the charge order in the Kagome materials, such as scanning tunneling microscopy, x-ray scattering and neutron scattering, the in-situ study using cryogenic transmission electron microscopy (TEM) has not been reported. Taking advantage of the high spatial resolution TEM, both imaging and diffraction, the study on Kagome materials may provide comprehensive understanding of the structural phase transition through electron diffraction.
